an5.71:3.1: 71 Freedom of Heart is the Fruit (1st)
an5.71:4.1: “Mendicants, these five things, when developed and cultivated, have freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom as their fruit and benefit.
an5.71:5.2: A mendicant meditates observing the ugliness of the body, perceives food as off-putting, perceives dissatisfaction with the whole world, observes the impermanence of all conditions, and has well established the perception of their own death.
an5.71:5.3: These five things, when developed and cultivated, have freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom as their fruit and benefit.
an5.71:5.4: When a mendicant has freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom,
an5.71:5.5: they’re called a mendicant who has lifted up the cross-bar, filled in the trench, and pulled up the pillar; they’re unbarred, a noble one with banner and burden put down, detached.
an5.71:6.1: And how has a mendicant lifted the cross-bar?
an5.71:6.2: It’s when a mendicant has given up ignorance, cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, exterminated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future.
an5.71:6.3: That’s how a mendicant has lifted the cross-bar.
an5.71:7.1: And how has a mendicant filled in the trench?
an5.71:7.2: It’s when a mendicant has given up transmigrating through births in future lives, cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, exterminated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future.
an5.71:7.3: That’s how a mendicant has filled in the trench.
an5.71:8.1: And how has a mendicant pulled up the pillar?
an5.71:8.2: It’s when a mendicant has given up craving, cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, exterminated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future.
an5.71:8.3: That’s how a mendicant has pulled up the pillar.
an5.71:9.1: And how is a mendicant unbarred?
an5.71:9.2: It’s when a mendicant has given up the five lower fetters, cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, exterminated them, so they’re unable to arise in the future.
an5.71:9.3: That’s how a mendicant is unbarred.
an5.71:10.1: And how is a mendicant a noble one with banner and burden put down, detached?
an5.71:10.2: It’s when a mendicant has given up the conceit ‘I am’, cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, exterminated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future.
an5.71:10.3: That’s how a mendicant is a noble one with banner and burden put down, detached.”
